Senior Writer at The Knicks Wall. Cellies with a Three-to-the-Dome. Founder of the Guillermo Gustavo Hernangomez Fan Club. Also Giants, Rangers, Yankees.
Dec 20, 2016

Is It Time to Bench Joakim Noah?

We look at whether having a struggling Noah in the starting unit is really with it or not

Joakim Noah’s tenure is New York thus far has been…uhm…bad? Does that cover it? Noah hasn’t helped as much offensively as many had hoped, and he has been an absolute train wreck defensively. His supposed defensive prowess was a big reason why he signed a $72 million deal in the offseason, but he’s looked awful on that end. He’s averaging just 4.4 points per game, and only 2.6 assists, his lowest assist total since 2011–12.

We knew that Noah’s best days had most likely passed him by, but there was speculation that a healthy and happy Noah could be rejuvenated coming to New York and provide the Knicks with a weapon at the pivot on both ends of the floor. That hasn’t happened. With the emergence of Kyle O’Quinn and Willy Hernangómez as solid big man options off the pine, the cries for Noah’s starting gig have been getting louder and louder.

With three and a half years and over $70 million still on Noah’s contract, is it time for the Knicks to move him to the bench?

If Noah was simply struggling and the Knicks had no options to replace him, this controversy wouldn’t exist. Fortunate for New York, however, they have two players that have been studs lately. O’Quinn and Hernangómez have been showing that they deserve more playing time, and that playing time can really only come at the expense of Noah. The 6'10" bearded dude out of Norfolk State has been showing Knicks fans that he is perhaps a good fit for that starting gig.

Kyle O’Quinn Continues the Knicks’ Tradition of Showing HBCU Athletes Can Ball
New York’s big man is another man following the steps of some Knicks greatstheknickswall.com

Kyle O’Quinn has seen his minutes get jostled around by Jeff Hornacek, but when given an opportunity to deliver, he has been impressive.

In December, he has had games with 22 and 14, eight and 11 with five assists, and 20 and 14. He’s averaging 10.1 points and 8.6 boards this month while shooting 62.7 percent from the floor in just over 20 minutes per game. He has (thankfully) stopped shooting three-pointers this year, attempting just five total. Instead of chucking hopeless threes, he has turned those threes into jumpers from just inside the arc. Almost 29 percent of his looks have come from 16 feet to the arc, and he’s shooting an incredible 55.6 percent on those shots. He has become a legitimate threat from a variety of areas on the floor, and has used his brute strength to become a force on the boards, pulling down over two offensive rebounds per game.

If those numbers don’t convince you, his ORtg is 118 while his DRtg is 106, according to Basketball-Reference. I loved O’Quinn when he was on the Magic (my college roommate is a Magic fan, so I spent plenty of time watching him), but he is showing that he is even more than any of us had previously imagined. He’ll never be a star, to be clear, but his fit on this team right now is more evident than a certain Mr. Noah.

(He still blocks us on Twitter though, so until that changes, I simply cannot advise that he enter the starting lineup. C’mon, Kyle, we’re trying to appease you here!)

Willy Hernangómez came into the NBA after being a second round pick in 2015. I did a profile on him this summer, and not to boast, but I think a lot of the things I said about him are true after watching his first couple months of NBA basketball. He is still young, and has plenty to learn on the defensive end of the floor, but wow, can the young man utilize his post game. (This is where I would post a Vine of him cooking some fools, but my laptop with my editing software is broken. Sigh. You’ll have to settle for this link for now.)

Who is Willy Hernangomez?
The Knicks’ 2015 NBA Draft trade acquisition might be reunited with his former teammate, Kristaps Porzingis, soontheknickswall.com

He is averaging 6.1 points and 5.2 rebounds in just 14 minutes per game, and those figures have been trending upwards recently. He had 17 and 10 against the Nuggets, and over the last three games he has played in, he’s put up 10.3 points and 10.7 boards while blocking 1.7 shots per game.

The positives in Willy’s game are obvious: he is a monster in the post, can finish with both hands, and has an innate ability to track down rebounds. The biggest concern for me with him is defense. Like I predicted over the summer, he has struggled to be much of a rim protector, allowing opponents to finish at a 59.6 percent clip within six feet. Again, important to consider how young he is, but for a guy that weighs 240 pounds, he seems to get pushed around a lot on the block. I’d love to read some reports over the summer about how he’s hitting the weight room to strengthen his core and lower half. Despite his defensive struggles, Hernangómez is a talented player, and deserves to see the floor.

Both of the brief profiles on O’Quinn and Hernangómez highlight the fact that they deserve more minutes, and those minutes are going to typically be with Joakim Noah on the bench. Since you will probably never see two of these guys on the court at the same time, minutes are going to be scarce, and Hornacek has begun to adjust to the declining Noah. O’Quinn has played more minutes per game than Noah in December, while Hernangómez is nipping at Noah’s heels.

Hornacek clearly realizes that the amount Noah has to offer on the floor is maximized by playing him in limited minutes.

The New Deal
We comb through some important details just released on the new Collective Bargaining Agreement and how they could…theknickswall.com

Which brings me to the question that this article kicks off with. I’ve said many times that starters are fairly irrelevant, as they only represent the players that play the first 4–6 minutes together on the floor. For most teams, their starting lineup is their best combination of five players, and those starters are the same unit that end games together. The Knicks have not been ending games with Noah on the floor. Considering this, and the fact that Noah has not performed well when put with bench units (he hasn’t performed well anywhere, really, but he’s been worse with most bench units than he has been with starters), I’m not sure if benching him is the answer right now.

Despite his struggles on the floor, he is still a huge source of leadership for this Knicks team, and benching him may create a bit of discourse between him and Hornacek. I think leaving Noah in the starting lineup while limiting his minutes is the best move for the foreseeable future. O’Quinn and Hernangómez deserves minutes, and they will get them, regardless of whether or not their name is penciled into the starting five. Benching Noah may prove to be the best move at some point this year, especially if the two bench bigs continue their resurgent play, but for right now, I’m just not sure a benching is in the best interest of the team.

O’Quinn would be the nominal starter with Noah hitting the pine, and the Knicks are 4–0 when he enters the starting lineup. I wouldn’t fault Hornacek at all if he made this switch. I would just hope that he had the requisite conversation with Noah to allow this team to continue to reap the benefits that Noah still brings to a team.

Regardless of the starters, Hornacek has a good problem on his hands: having too many big bodies with not enough minutes to go around.

— Matt Spendley, senior writer
